CHM 101.question: Will magnesium displace zinc from zinc chloride solution?

options.A: Yes, because magnesium is less reactive than zinc.
options.B: No, because magnesium is less reactive than zinc.
options.C: Yes, because magnesium is more reactive than zinc.
options.D: No, because magnesium and zinc are equally reactive.

CHM 101.explanation: Magnesium is more reactive than zinc, so it can displace zinc from its compound.
CHM 101.hint: Check the positions of magnesium and zinc in the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Will iron displace copper from copper nitrate solution?

options.A: Yes, because iron is less reactive than copper.
options.B: No, because iron is less reactive than copper.
options.C: Yes, because iron is more reactive than copper.
options.D: No, because they form an insoluble product.

CHM 101.explanation: Iron is more reactive than copper, so it will displace copper from its solution.
CHM 101.hint: Iron is higher in the reactivity series than copper.

CHM 101.question: Will silver displace lead from lead acetate solution?

options.A: Yes, because silver is more reactive than lead.
options.B: No, because silver is less reactive than lead.
options.D: No, because silver only reacts with acids.

CHM 101.explanation: Silver is less reactive than lead, so it cannot displace lead from its compound.
CHM 101.hint: Silver is below lead in the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Will zinc displace iron from iron(II) sulfate solution?

options.A: Yes, because zinc is more reactive than iron.
options.B: No, because zinc is less reactive than iron.
options.C: Yes, because they are both moderately reactive.
options.D: No, because the reaction would be too slow.

CHM 101.explanation: Zinc is more reactive than iron, so it can displace iron from its salt solution.
CHM 101.hint: Zinc is placed above iron in the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Will copper displace silver from silver nitrate solution?

options.A: Yes, because copper is more reactive than silver.
options.B: No, because copper is less reactive than silver.
options.C: Yes, because copper is more expensive.
options.D: No, because silver nitrate is not soluble.

CHM 101.explanation: Copper is more reactive than silver, so it will displace silver, forming copper nitrate and solid silver.
CHM 101.hint: Copper is above silver in the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Will potassium displace sodium from sodium chloride solution?

options.A: Yes, because potassium is more reactive than sodium.
options.B: No, because potassium is less reactive than sodium.
options.C: Yes, because they are both alkali metals.
options.D: No, because the reaction with water would interfere.

CHM 101.explanation: While potassium is more reactive than sodium, it would react violently with the water in the solution first, rather than displacing sodium in a straightforward manner.
CHM 101.hint: Potassium reacts explosively with water, so it would react with the solvent.

CHM 101.question: Will tin displace magnesium from magnesium sulfate solution?

options.A: Yes, because tin is more reactive than magnesium.
options.B: No, because tin is less reactive than magnesium.
options.C: Yes, because both are extracted by carbon reduction.
options.D: No, because magnesium sulfate is insoluble.

CHM 101.explanation: Tin is less reactive than magnesium, so it cannot displace magnesium from its compound.
CHM 101.hint: Magnesium is much higher in the reactivity series than tin.

CHM 101.question: Will lead displace zinc from zinc sulfate solution?

options.A: Yes, because lead is more reactive than zinc.
options.B: No, because lead is less reactive than zinc.
options.D: No, because zinc sulfate is a weak electrolyte.

CHM 101.explanation: Lead is less reactive than zinc, so it cannot displace zinc.
CHM 101.hint: In the series, zinc is above lead.

CHM 101.question: Will aluminium displace iron from iron(III) oxide?

options.A: Yes, because aluminium is more reactive than iron.
options.B: No, because aluminium is less reactive than iron.
options.C: Yes, but only at very high temperatures (thermite reaction).
options.D: No, because aluminium forms a protective oxide layer.

CHM 101.explanation: Aluminium is more reactive than iron. This displacement is the basis of the thermite reaction, but it requires high heat to initiate.
CHM 101.hint: This is a specific, well-known extraction reaction for iron.

CHM 101.question: Will gold displace copper from copper sulfate solution?

options.A: Yes, because gold is more valuable.
options.B: No, because gold is less reactive than copper.
options.C: Yes, because gold is more reactive than copper.
options.D: No, because copper sulfate would tarnish the gold.

CHM 101.explanation: Gold is much less reactive than copper, so it cannot displace copper.
CHM 101.hint: Gold is at the very bottom of the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Will calcium displace aluminium from aluminium oxide?

options.A: Yes, because calcium is more reactive than aluminium.
options.B: No, because calcium is less reactive than aluminium.
options.C: Yes, but only in an aqueous solution.
options.D: No, because aluminium oxide is very stable.

CHM 101.explanation: Calcium is more reactive than aluminium, so it can displace aluminium from its oxide, though this may require specific conditions.
CHM 101.hint: Calcium is above aluminium in the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Will sodium displace potassium from potassium hydroxide solution?

options.A: Yes, because sodium is more reactive.
options.B: No, because sodium is less reactive than potassium.
options.C: Yes, because they are both in Group 1.
options.D: No, because potassium hydroxide is a base, not a salt.

CHM 101.explanation: Sodium is less reactive than potassium, so it cannot displace potassium. Furthermore, sodium would react violently with the water in the solution.
CHM 101.hint: Potassium is the most reactive metal.

CHM 101.question: Will magnesium displace aluminium from aluminium chloride solution?

options.A: Yes, because magnesium is more reactive.
options.B: No, because magnesium is less reactive than aluminium.
options.C: Yes, because aluminium chloride is acidic.
options.D: No, because a passive layer forms on magnesium.

CHM 101.explanation: Magnesium is less reactive than aluminium, so it cannot displace aluminium from its compound.
CHM 101.hint: Check their order in the series: Aluminium comes after Magnesium.

CHM 101.question: Will zinc displace tin from tin(II) chloride solution?

options.A: Yes, because zinc is more reactive than tin.
options.B: No, because zinc is less reactive than tin.
options.D: No, because tin(II) chloride hydrolyzes in water.

CHM 101.explanation: Zinc is more reactive than tin, so it will displace tin.
CHM 101.hint: Zinc is placed above tin in the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Will iron displace magnesium from magnesium chloride solution?

options.A: Yes, because iron is more reactive.
options.B: No, because iron is less reactive than magnesium.
options.C: Yes, because magnesium is an alkaline earth metal.
options.D: No, because magnesium chloride is hygroscopic.

CHM 101.explanation: Iron is less reactive than magnesium, so it cannot displace magnesium.
CHM 101.hint: Magnesium is much higher in the series than iron.

CHM 101.question: Will copper displace gold from gold chloride solution?

options.A: Yes, because copper is more reactive than gold.
options.B: No, because copper is less reactive than gold.
options.D: No, because gold chloride is unstable.

CHM 101.explanation: Copper is more reactive than gold, so it can displace gold from its compounds.
CHM 101.hint: This is a classic test for gold ions in solution.

CHM 101.question: Will lead displace copper from copper sulfate solution?

options.A: Yes, because lead is more reactive.
options.B: No, because lead is less reactive than copper.
options.C: Yes, because lead ions are colorless.
options.D: No, because lead sulfate is insoluble and coats the metal.

CHM 101.explanation: While lead is theoretically more reactive than copper, the lead sulfate formed in the reaction is insoluble and forms a coating that stops the reaction. Therefore, in practice, the displacement does not proceed.
CHM 101.hint: Practical observations sometimes differ from theoretical predictions due to product solubility.

CHM 101.question: Will silver displace hydrogen from dilute hydrochloric acid?

options.B: No, because silver is below hydrogen in the reactivity series.
options.C: Yes, because all metals react with acids.
options.D: No, because silver forms an insoluble chloride layer.

CHM 101.explanation: Silver is below hydrogen in the reactivity series, so it does not react with dilute acids to produce hydrogen gas.
CHM 101.hint: Only metals above hydrogen displace hydrogen from acids.

CHM 101.question: Will a strip of magnesium displace hydrogen from dilute sulfuric acid?

options.A: Yes, because magnesium is above hydrogen.
options.B: No, because magnesium is below hydrogen.
options.C: No, because sulfuric acid is oxidizing.
options.D: Yes, but only if the acid is concentrated.

CHM 101.explanation: Magnesium is well above hydrogen in the reactivity series and will react vigorously with dilute sulfuric acid to produce magnesium sulfate and hydrogen gas.
CHM 101.hint: This is a standard laboratory test for hydrogen production.

CHM 101.question: What is the reactivity series?

options.A: A list of metals arranged by their atomic mass.
options.B: A list of metals arranged by their density.
options.C: A list of metals arranged in order of decreasing reactivity.
options.D: A list of metals arranged by their melting point.

CHM 101.explanation: The reactivity series is a list of metals arranged in order of decreasing reactivity.
CHM 101.hint: It is also called the activity series.

CHM 101.question: Which metal is at the top of the reactivity series?

options.B: Calcium (Ca)
options.D: Magnesium (Mg)

CHM 101.explanation: Potassium (K) is the most reactive metal in the series.
CHM 101.hint: The series is in order of decreasing reactivity.

CHM 101.question: Which of these metals is the least reactive?

options.B: Zinc (Zn)
options.D: Aluminium (Al)

CHM 101.explanation: Gold (Au) is one of the least reactive metals in the series.
CHM 101.hint: Gold is often found free in nature.

CHM 101.question: In the mnemonic 'Please Stop Calling Me A Careless Zebra Instead Try Learning How Copper Saves Gold', which metal does 'Careless' represent?

options.B: Zinc
options.D: Copper

CHM 101.explanation: In the given mnemonic, 'Careless' represents Zinc (Zn).
CHM 101.hint: The sequence is: Please (Potassium), Stop (Sodium), Calling (Calcium), Me (Magnesium), A (Aluminium), Careless (Zinc).

CHM 101.question: What does a metal being 'more reactive' mean?

options.B: It is a very good conductor of heat.
options.C: It loses electrons easily and forms compounds readily.
options.D: It has a very high density.

CHM 101.explanation: A more reactive metal loses electrons easily, reacts quickly with water or acids, and forms compounds readily.
CHM 101.hint: Reactivity is related to the ease of losing electrons.

CHM 101.question: Where are highly reactive metals typically found in nature?

options.B: Combined in compounds or ores.
options.D: Floating on water.

CHM 101.explanation: Highly reactive metals are usually found combined in nature, while less reactive metals may be found free or uncombined.
CHM 101.hint: Their high reactivity means they readily form compounds with other elements.

CHM 101.question: Which metals react violently with cold water?

options.B: Potassium and Sodium
options.D: Copper and Silver

CHM 101.explanation: Potassium and Sodium react violently with cold water.
CHM 101.hint: The reaction produces hydrogen gas and a lot of heat.

CHM 101.question: What are the products when sodium reacts with water?

options.B: Sodium chloride and Water
options.D: Sodium carbonate and Oxygen

CHM 101.explanation: Sodium + Water → Sodium hydroxide + Hydrogen. The equation is 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂.
CHM 101.hint: The reaction forms a metal hydroxide and hydrogen gas.

CHM 101.question: Which metal reacts slowly with cold water?

options.B: Sodium
options.D: Magnesium

CHM 101.explanation: Calcium reacts slowly with cold water.
CHM 101.hint: Its reaction is less violent than potassium or sodium.

CHM 101.question: Which metals react only with steam, not cold water?

options.B: Magnesium, Zinc, Iron
options.D: Aluminium, Tin, Lead

CHM 101.explanation: Magnesium, Zinc, and Iron react with steam but not with cold water.
CHM 101.hint: They require the higher energy of steam to react.

CHM 101.question: What is the product when magnesium reacts with steam?

options.B: Magnesium chloride and Water
options.D: Magnesium sulfate and Oxygen

CHM 101.explanation: Mg + H₂O (steam) → MgO + H₂.
CHM 101.hint: The reaction with steam produces a metal oxide, not a hydroxide.

CHM 101.question: Which of the following metals does NOT react with water at all?

options.B: Iron
options.D: Magnesium

CHM 101.explanation: Copper, along with Silver and Gold, does not react with water.
CHM 101.hint: These metals are low in the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: With dilute acids, what do metals above hydrogen in the reactivity series produce?

options.B: Salt and Hydrogen gas
options.D: Metal hydroxide and Oxygen

CHM 101.explanation: Metals above hydrogen react with dilute acids to produce salt and hydrogen gas.
CHM 101.hint: The general equation is: Metal + Acid → Salt + Hydrogen.

CHM 101.question: Which of these reactions represents a metal reacting with a dilute acid?

options.B: Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl₂ + H₂
options.D: Au + 2HCl → AuCl₂ + H₂

CHM 101.explanation: Zinc, being above hydrogen, reacts with hydrochloric acid to form zinc chloride and hydrogen.
CHM 101.hint: Zinc is more reactive than hydrogen.

CHM 101.question: Why do metals like copper, silver, and gold not react with dilute acids?

options.B: They are below hydrogen in the reactivity series.
options.D: They only react with concentrated acids.

CHM 101.explanation: Metals below hydrogen in the reactivity series, such as copper, silver, and gold, do not react with dilute acids.
CHM 101.hint: Hydrogen is a key reference point in the series for acid reactions.

CHM 101.question: What is a displacement reaction?

options.A: A reaction where two metals combine to form an alloy.
options.B: A reaction where a more reactive metal displaces a less reactive metal from its compound.
options.C: A reaction where a metal reacts with water to form a hydroxide.
options.D: A reaction where a metal decomposes upon heating.

CHM 101.explanation: A displacement reaction occurs when a more reactive metal displaces a less reactive metal from its compound.
CHM 101.hint: The more reactive metal takes the place of the less reactive one.

CHM 101.question: In the reaction Zn + CuSO₄ → ZnSO₄ + Cu, why does zinc displace copper?

options.A: Zinc is less reactive than copper.
options.B: Zinc is more reactive than copper.
options.D: Copper sulfate is a weak compound.

CHM 101.explanation: Zinc displaces copper from copper sulfate because zinc is more reactive than copper.
CHM 101.hint: A more reactive metal can displace a less reactive one.

CHM 101.question: Can iron displace zinc from a solution of zinc sulfate?

options.A: Yes, because iron is more reactive than zinc.
options.B: No, because zinc is more reactive than iron.
options.C: Yes, because they are both moderately reactive.
options.D: No, because they form an alloy instead.

CHM 101.explanation: Iron cannot displace zinc because zinc is more reactive than iron. A less reactive metal cannot displace a more reactive metal.
CHM 101.hint: Check the positions of iron and zinc in the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Which method is used to extract highly reactive metals like aluminium?

options.B: Heating alone
options.D: Displacement with a less reactive metal

CHM 101.explanation: Highly reactive metals (K, Na, Ca, Mg, Al) are extracted by electrolysis.
CHM 101.hint: Their strong hold on electrons requires a powerful method like electrolysis.

CHM 101.question: How are moderately reactive metals like iron extracted?

options.B: By electrolysis.
options.C: By reduction with carbon or carbon monoxide.
options.D: By displacement with sodium.

CHM 101.explanation: Moderately reactive metals (Zn, Fe, Sn, Pb) are extracted by reduction with carbon or carbon monoxide.
CHM 101.hint: The reaction involves removing oxygen from the ore.

CHM 101.question: Why are metals like gold and silver often found free in nature?

options.A: They are highly soluble in water.
options.B: They are very reactive and form compounds easily.
options.C: They are very unreactive and do not readily form compounds.
options.D: They are magnetic.

CHM 101.explanation: Least reactive metals (Cu, Ag, Au) are found free in nature because they are very unreactive and do not readily combine with other elements.
CHM 101.hint: Their low position in the reactivity series explains this.

CHM 101.question: Which metal is extracted from bauxite by electrolysis?

options.B: Copper
options.D: Zinc

CHM 101.explanation: Aluminium is extracted from its ore, bauxite, by electrolysis.
CHM 101.hint: Aluminium is a highly reactive metal.

CHM 101.question: Why does iron rust easily while gold does not?

options.B: Iron is higher in the reactivity series and corrodes easily.
options.D: Iron is magnetic.

CHM 101.explanation: Metals high in the reactivity series, like iron, corrode easily. Gold, being very low in the series, is very unreactive and resists corrosion.
CHM 101.hint: Rusting is a form of corrosion involving reaction with oxygen and water.

CHM 101.question: What is the purpose of using zinc for sacrificial protection of iron?

options.B: Zinc is more reactive than iron and corrodes first, protecting the iron.
options.C: Zinc forms a more attractive layer.
options.D: Zinc is less reactive and provides a physical barrier.

CHM 101.explanation: Zinc is used for sacrificial protection because it is more reactive than iron. It will corrode preferentially, thereby protecting the iron from rusting.
CHM 101.hint: This is an application based on the reactivity series.

CHM 101.question: Which of the following is NOT a use of the reactivity series?

options.A: Predicting reactions between metals and water.
options.B: Determining the color of metal salts.
options.C: Choosing suitable methods for metal extraction.
options.D: Predicting displacement reactions.

CHM 101.explanation: The reactivity series is used to predict reactions with water and acids, determine displacement reactions, choose extraction methods, and prevent corrosion. It is not used to determine the color of salts.
CHM 101.hint: The series relates to chemical reactivity, not physical properties like color.

CHM 101.question: In the shorter mnemonic 'King Solomon Can Make A Zebra Iron Tin Lead Copper Silver Gold', which metal does 'Make' represent?

options.B: Aluminium
options.D: Iron

CHM 101.explanation: In the mnemonic 'King Solomon Can Make A Zebra...', 'Make' represents Magnesium (Mg).
CHM 101.hint: The sequence is: King (Potassium), Solomon (Sodium), Can (Calcium), Make (Magnesium).

CHM 101.question: What is the correct order of reactivity from most reactive to least reactive?

options.A: Na, K, Ca, Mg, Al, Zn, Fe, Sn, Pb, Cu, Ag, Au
options.B: K, Na, Ca, Mg, Al, Zn, Fe, Sn, Pb, Cu, Ag, Au
options.C: Au, Ag, Cu, Pb, Sn, Fe, Zn, Al, Mg, Ca, Na, K
options.D: K, Ca, Na, Mg, Al, Zn, Fe, Pb, Sn, Cu, Ag, Au

CHM 101.explanation: The correct order is: Potassium (K), Sodium (Na), Calcium (Ca), Magnesium (Mg), Aluminium (Al), Zinc (Zn), Iron (Fe), Tin (Sn), Lead (Pb), Copper (Cu), Silver (Ag), Gold (Au).
CHM 101.hint: Potassium is always first, gold is last.

CHM 101.question: Which metal would safely displace silver from a solution of silver nitrate?

options.B: Gold
options.D: Silver

CHM 101.explanation: Copper is more reactive than silver, so it can displace silver from silver nitrate. Gold and platinum are less reactive than silver.
CHM 101.hint: The displacing metal must be higher in the series than the metal in the compound.

CHM 101.question: What is the main gas produced when a reactive metal reacts with a dilute acid?

options.B: Carbon dioxide
options.D: Nitrogen

CHM 101.explanation: The reaction between a metal above hydrogen and a dilute acid produces hydrogen gas.
CHM 101.hint: The general equation is Metal + Acid → Salt + Hydrogen.

CHM 101.question: Why is carbon not used to extract aluminium from its ore?

options.B: Aluminium is more reactive than carbon.
options.C: Carbon does not react with aluminium ore.
options.D: The process would produce too much heat.

CHM 101.explanation: Aluminium is more reactive than carbon. Highly reactive metals cannot be reduced by carbon; they require electrolysis.
CHM 101.hint: Carbon can only reduce metals that are less reactive than itself.

CHM 101.question: Which of the following equations correctly shows the extraction of iron?

options.B: Al₂O₃ → 2Al + 3O₂
options.D: CuO + C → Cu + CO

CHM 101.explanation: Iron oxide is reduced by carbon monoxide in the blast furnace: Fe₂O₃ + 3CO → 2Fe + 3CO₂.
CHM 101.hint: Iron is a moderately reactive metal extracted by reduction.

CHM 101.question: If a metal does not react with water or dilute acids, where is it likely to be found in the reactivity series?

options.B: In the middle.
options.D: Between magnesium and zinc.

CHM 101.explanation: Metals that do not react with water or dilute acids are below hydrogen in the reactivity series.
CHM 101.hint: Hydrogen is a benchmark for reaction with acids.

CHM 101.question: What is formed when calcium reacts with water?

options.B: Calcium hydroxide and Hydrogen
options.D: Calcium chloride and Oxygen

CHM 101.explanation: Calcium reacts with cold water to form calcium hydroxide and hydrogen gas: Ca + 2H₂O → Ca(OH)₂ + H₂.
CHM 101.hint: The reaction with cold water produces a hydroxide.

CHM 101.question: Which metal's reaction with water is so vigorous it can cause fire?

options.B: Calcium
options.D: Aluminium

CHM 101.explanation: The reaction of potassium and sodium with cold water is violent and produces enough heat to ignite the hydrogen gas.
CHM 101.hint: These are the most reactive metals with water.

CHM 101.question: In the context of the reactivity series, what does 'reduction with carbon' mean?

options.A: Adding carbon to increase the metal's mass.
options.B: Using carbon to remove oxygen from a metal ore.
options.C: Mixing carbon with the metal to form an alloy.
options.D: Heating carbon with the metal to make it shinier.

CHM 101.explanation: Reduction with carbon involves using carbon (or carbon monoxide) to remove oxygen from a metal oxide ore, leaving the pure metal.
CHM 101.hint: It is a common extraction method for metals like iron.
